rationale: The examined life requires us to act with wisdom. Saving five lives demonstrates care for the greater good.
We cannot use one person as a mere means to save others. The moral law forbids such instrumentalization.
The essence of the ship lies in its form and purpose. The crew maintains this continuity.
The greatest happiness principle demands we save the greater number.
Justice requires respecting legal frameworks. The elderly person followed the rules.
Years of potential life matter. The utilitarian calculus favors saving the younger person.
First, do no harm. A physician must never actively harm a healthy patient.
The hedonic calculus is clear: five lives produce more happiness than one.
Non-identity problems aside, preventing suffering for existing people takes priority.
We cannot violate the rights of those who exist, even to prevent future harms.
